1497            <section title="Creating an Authenticated Enveloped-Only Message" anchor="AuthEnvelopedData2">
1498              <t>
1499                This section describes the format for enveloping a MIME entity without signing it.
1500                Authenticated enveloped messages provide confidentiality and data integrity.
1501                It is important to note that sending authenticated enveloped  messages does not provide for origination when using S/MIME.
1502                It is possible for a third party to replace ciphertext in such a way that the processed message will still be valid, but the meaning can be altered.
1503                However this is substantially more difficult than it is for an enveloped-only message as the algorithm does provide a level of authentication.
1504                Any recipient for whom the message is encrypted can replace it without detection.
1505              </t>
1506              <t>
1507              <list style="format Step %d.">
1508                  <t>
1509                    The MIME entity to be enveloped is prepared according to <xref target="MimePrep"/>.
1510                  </t>
1511                  
1512                  <t>
1513                    The MIME entity and other required data is processed into a CMS object of type AuthEnvelopedData.
1514                    In addition to encrypting a copy of the content-encryption key for each recipient, a copy of the content-encryption key SHOULD
1515                    be encrypted for the originator and included in the AuthEnvelopedData (see <xref target="RFC5083"/>).
1516                  </t>
1517                  
1518                  <t>
1519                    The AuthEnvelopedData object is wrapped in a CMS ContentInfo object.
1520                  </t>
1521                  
1522                  <t>
1523                    The ContentInfo object is inserted into an application/&wj;pkcs7-mime MIME entity.
1524                  </t>
1525                  
1526                </list>
1527              </t>
1528              
1529              <t>
1530                The smime-type parameter for authenticated enveloped-only messages is "authEnveloped-data".
1531                The file extension for this type of message is ".p7m".
1532              </t>
1533              <t>
1534
1535                A sample message would be:
1536              </t>
1537              <figure>
1538                <artwork>
1539Content-Type: application/pkcs7-mime; smime-type=authEnveloped-data;
1540      name=smime.p7m
1541Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
1542Content-Disposition: attachment; filename=smime.p7m
1543
1544MIIDWQYLKoZIhvcNAQkQARegggNIMIIDRAIBADGBvjCBuwIBADAmMBIxEDAO
1545BgNVBAMTB0NhcmxSU0ECEEY0a8eAAFa8EdNuLs1dcdAwCwYJKoZIhvcNAQEB
1546BIGAgyZJo0ERTxA4xdTri5P5tVMyh0RARepTUCORZvlUbcUlaI8IpJZH3/J1
1547Fv6MxTRS4O/K+ZcTlQmYeWLQvwdltQdOIP3mhpqXzTnOYhTK1IDtF2zx75Lg
1548vE+ilpcLIzXfJB4RCBPtBWaHAof4Wb+VMQvLkk9OolX4mRSH1LPktgAwggJq
1549BgkqhkiG9w0BBwEwGwYJYIZIAWUDBAEGMA4EDGPizioC9OHSsnNx4oCCAj7Y
1550Cb8rOy8+55106newEJohC/aDgWbJhrMKzSOwa7JraXOV3HXD3NvKbl665dRx
1551vmDwSCNaLCRU5q8/AxQx2SvnAbM+JKcEfC/VFdd4SiHNiUECAApLku2rMi5B
1552WrhW/FXmx9d+cjum2BRwB3wj0q1wajdB0/kVRbQwg697dnlYyUog4vpJERjr
15537KAkawZx1RMHaM18wgZjUNpCBXFS3chQi9mTBp2i2Hf5iZ8OOtTx+rCQUmI6
1554Jhy03vdcPCCARBjn3v0d3upZYDZddMA41CB9fKnnWFjadV1KpYwv80tqsEfx
1555Vo0lJQ5VtJ8MHJiBpLVKadRIZ4iH2ULC0JtN5mXE1SrFKh7cqbJ4+7nqSRL3

1557ghHbvSqhIsXFzRSWKiZOigmlkv3R5LnjpYyP4brM62Jl7y0qborvV4dNMz7m

15636Zeu2ZwE
1564              </artwork>
1565              </figure>
1566            </section>
1567            <section title="Creating a Signed-Only Message" anchor="Signed-Only">
1568              <t>
1569                There are two formats for signed messages defined for S/&wj;MIME:
1570                <list style="symbols">
1571                  <t>
1572                    application/&wj;pkcs7-mime with SignedData.
1573                  </t>
1574                  <t>
1575
1576                    multipart/signed.
1577                  </t>
1578                </list>
1579              </t>
1580              <t>
1581                In general, the multipart/signed form is preferred for sending, and
1582                receiving agents MUST be able to handle both.
1583              </t>
1584              <section title="Choosing a Format for Signed-Only Messages">
1585                <t>
1586                  There are no hard-and-fast rules as to when a particular signed-only
1587                  format is chosen.  It depends on the capabilities of all the
1588                  receivers and the relative importance of receivers with S/&wj;MIME
1589                  facilities being able to verify the signature versus the importance
1590                  of receivers without S/&wj;MIME software being able to view the message.
1591                </t>
1592                <t>
1593                  Messages signed using the multipart/&wj;signed format can always be
1594                  viewed by the receiver whether or not they have S/&wj;MIME software.
1595                  They can also be viewed whether they are using a MIME-native user
1596                  agent or they have messages translated by a gateway.  In this
1597                  context, "be viewed" means the ability to process the message
1598                  essentially as if it were not a signed message, including any other
1599                  MIME structure the message might have.
1600                </t>
1601                <t>
1602
1603                  Messages signed using the SignedData format cannot be viewed by a
1604                  recipient unless they have S/&wj;MIME facilities.  However, the
1605                  SignedData format protects the message content from being changed by
1606                  benign intermediate agents.  Such agents might do line wrapping or
1607                  content-transfer encoding changes that would break the signature.
1608                </t>
1609              </section>
1610              <section title="Signing Using application/pkcs7-mime with SignedData">
1611                <t>
1612                  This signing format uses the application/&wj;pkcs7-mime media type.  The
1613                  steps to create this format are:
1614
1615                  <list style="format Step %d.">
1616                  <t>  The MIME entity is prepared according to <xref target="MimePrep"/>.
1617</t>
1618                  <t>  The MIME entity and other required data are processed into a
1619                  CMS object of type SignedData.
1620                  </t>
1621                  <t>  The SignedData object is wrapped in a CMS ContentInfo
1622                  object.
1623</t>
1624                  <t>  The ContentInfo object is inserted into an
1625                  application/&wj;pkcs7-mime MIME entity.
1626                  </t>
1627                  </list>
1628                </t>
1629                <t>
1630                  The smime-type parameter for messages using application/&wj;pkcs7-mime
1631                  with SignedData is "signed-data".  The file extension for this type
1632                  of message is ".p7m".
1633                </t>
1634                <t>
1635                  A sample message would be:
1636                </t>
1637                <figure>
1638                <artwork>
1639Content-Type: application/pkcs7-mime; smime-type=signed-data;
1640    name=smime.p7m
1641Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
1642Content-Disposition: attachment; filename=smime.p7m
1643
1644MIIDmQYJKoZIhvcNAQcCoIIDijCCA4YCAQExCTAHBgUrDgMCGjAtBgkqhkiG9w0BBw
1645GgIAQeDQpUaGlzIGlzIHNvbWUgc2FtcGxlIGNvbnRlbnQuoIIC4DCCAtwwggKboAMC
1646AQICAgDIMAkGByqGSM44BAMwEjEQMA4GA1UEAxMHQ2FybERTUzAeFw05OTA4MTcwMT
1647EwNDlaFw0zOTEyMzEyMzU5NTlaMBMxETAPBgNVBAMTCEFsaWNlRFNTMIIBtjCCASsG
1648ByqGSM44BAEwggEeAoGBAIGNze2D6gqeOT7CSCij5EeT3Q7XqA7sU8WrhAhP/5Thc0
1649h+DNbzREjR/p+vpKGJL+HZMMg23j+bv7dM3F9piuR10DcMkQiVm96nXvn89J8v3UOo
1650i1TxP7AHCEdNXYjDw7Wz41UIddU5dhDEeL3/nbCElzfy5FEbteQJllzzflvbAhUA4k
1651emGkVmuBPG2o+4NyErYov3k80CgYAmONAUiTKqOfs+bdlLWWpMdiM5BAI1XPLLGjDD
1652HlBd3ZtZ4s2qBT1YwHuiNrhuB699ikIlp/R1z0oIXks+kPht6pzJIYo7dhTpzi5dow
1653fNI4W4LzABfG1JiRGJNkS9+MiVSlNWteL5c+waYTYfEX/Cve3RUP+YdMLRgUpgObo2
1654OQOBhAACgYBc47ladRSWC6l63eM/qeysXty9txMRNKYWiSgRI9k0hmd1dRMSPUNbb+
1655VRv/qJ8qIbPiR9PQeNW2PIu0WloErjhdbOBoA/6CN+GvIkq1MauCcNHu8Iv2YUgFxi
1656rGX6FYvxuzTU0pY39mFHssQyhPB+QUD9RqdjTjPypeL08oPluKOBgTB/MAwGA1UdEw
1657EB/wQCMAAwDgYDVR0PAQH/BAQDAgbAMB8GA1UdIwQYMBaAFHBEPoIub4feStN14z0g
1658vEMrk/EfMB0GA1UdDgQWBBS+bKGz48H37UNwpM4TAeL945f+zTAfBgNVHREEGDAWgR
1659RBbGljZURTU0BleGFtcGxlLmNvbTAJBgcqhkjOOAQDAzAAMC0CFFUMpBkfQiuJcSIz
1660jYNqtT1na79FAhUAn2FTUlQLXLLd2ud2HeIQUltDXr0xYzBhAgEBMBgwEjEQMA4GA1
1661UEAxMHQ2FybERTUwICAMgwBwYFKw4DAhowCQYHKoZIzjgEAwQuMCwCFD1cSW6LIUFz
1662eXle3YI5SKSBer/sAhQmCq7s/CTFHOEjgASeUjbMpx5g6A==
1663                </artwork>
1664                </figure>
1665              </section>
1666              
1667              <section title="Signing Using the multipart/signed Format" anchor="SignMultipart">
1668                <t>
1669                  This format is a clear-signing format.  Recipients without any S/&wj;MIME
1670                  or CMS processing facilities are able to view the message.  It makes
1671                  use of the multipart/&wj;signed media type described in <xref target="RFC1847"/>.
1672                  The multipart/&wj;signed media type has two parts.  The first part
1673                  contains the MIME entity that is signed; the second part contains the
1674                  "detached signature" CMS SignedData object in which the
1675                  encapContentInfo eContent field is absent.
1676                </t>
1677              
1678
1679
1680
1681
1682              <section title="The application/pkcs7-signature Media Type">
1683                <t>
1684                  This media type always contains a CMS ContentInfo containing a single
1685                  CMS object of type SignedData.  The SignedData encapContentInfo
1686                  eContent field MUST be absent.  The signerInfos field contains the
1687                  signatures for the MIME entity.
1688                </t>
1689                <t>
1690                  The file extension for signed-only messages using application/&wj;pkcs7-
1691                  signature is ".p7s".
1692                </t>
1693              </section>
1694              
1695              <section title="Creating a multipart/signed Message">
1696                <t>
1697                  <list style="format Step %d.">
1698                  <t>  The MIME entity to be signed is prepared according to
1699                  <xref target="MimePrep"/>, taking special care for clear-signing.
1700</t>
1701                  <t>  The MIME entity is presented to CMS processing in order to
1702                  obtain an object of type SignedData in which the
1703                  encapContentInfo eContent field is absent.
1704</t>
1705                  <t>  The MIME entity is inserted into the first part of a
1706                  multipart/&wj;signed message with no processing other than that
1707                  described in <xref target="MimePrep"/>.
1708</t>
1709                  <t>  Transfer encoding is applied to the "detached signature" CMS
1710                  SignedData object, and it is inserted into a MIME entity of
1711                  type application/&wj;pkcs7-signature.
1712</t>
1713                  <t>  The MIME entity of the application/&wj;pkcs7-signature is
1714                  inserted into the second part of the multipart/&wj;signed
1715                  entity.
1716</t>
1717                  </list>
1718                </t>
1719                <t>
1720                  The multipart/&wj;signed Content-Type has two required parameters: the
1721                  protocol parameter and the micalg parameter.
1722                </t>
1723                <t>
1724                  The protocol parameter MUST be "application/&wj;pkcs7-signature".  Note
1725                  that quotation marks are required around the protocol parameter
1726                  because MIME requires that the "/" character in the parameter value
1727                  MUST be quoted.
1728                </t>
1729                <t>
1730                  The micalg parameter allows for one-pass processing when the
1731                  signature is being verified.  The value of the micalg parameter is
1732                  dependent on the message digest algorithm(s) used in the calculation
1733                  of the Message Integrity Check.  If multiple message digest
1734                  algorithms are used, they MUST be separated by commas per <xref target="RFC1847"/>.
1735                    The values to be placed in the micalg parameter SHOULD be
1736                  from the following:
1737                </t>
1738
1739                <texttable style="none">
1740                  <ttcol>Algorithm</ttcol><ttcol>Value Used</ttcol>
1741                  <c>MD5</c><c>md5</c>
1742                  <c>SHA-1</c><c>sha-1</c>
1743                  <c>SHA-224</c><c>sha-224</c>
1744                  <c>SHA-256</c><c>sha-256</c>
1745                  <c>SHA-384</c><c>sha-384</c>
1746                  <c>SHA-512</c><c>sha-512</c>
1747                  <c>Any other</c><c>  (defined separately in algorithm profile or "unknown" if not defined)</c>
1748                </texttable>
1749                
1750                <t>
1751                  (Historical note: some early implementations of S/MIME emitted and
1752                  expected "rsa-md5", "rsa-sha1", and "sha1" for the micalg parameter.)
1753                  Receiving agents SHOULD be able to recover gracefully from a micalg
1754                  parameter value that they do not recognize.  Future names for this
1755                  parameter will be consistent with the IANA "Hash Function Textual
1756                  Names" registry.
1757                </t>
1758              </section>
1759              <section title="Sample multipart/signed Message">
1760                <figure>
1761                  <artwork>
1762Content-Type: multipart/signed;
1763    micalg=sha-1;
1764    boundary="----=_NextBoundry____Fri,_06_Sep_2002_00:25:21";
1765    protocol="application/pkcs7-signature"
1766
1767This is a multi-part message in MIME format.
1768
1769------=_NextBoundry____Fri,_06_Sep_2002_00:25:21
1770
1771This is some sample content.
1772------=_NextBoundry____Fri,_06_Sep_2002_00:25:21
1773Content-Type: application/pkcs7-signature; name=smime.p7s
1774Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
1775Content-Disposition: attachment; filename=smime.p7s
1776
1777MIIDdwYJKoZIhvcNAQcCoIIDaDCCA2QCAQExCTAHBgUrDgMCGjALBgkqhkiG9w0BBw
1778GgggLgMIIC3DCCApugAwIBAgICAMgwCQYHKoZIzjgEAzASMRAwDgYDVQQDEwdDYXJs
1779RFNTMB4XDTk5MDgxNzAxMTA0OVoXDTM5MTIzMTIzNTk1OVowEzERMA8GA1UEAxMIQW
1780xpY2VEU1MwggG2MIIBKwYHKoZIzjgEATCCAR4CgYEAgY3N7YPqCp45PsJIKKPkR5Pd
1781DteoDuxTxauECE//lOFzSH4M1vNESNH+n6+koYkv4dkwyDbeP5u/t0zcX2mK5HXQNw
1782yRCJWb3qde+fz0ny/dQ6iLVPE/sAcIR01diMPDtbPjVQh11Tl2EMR4vf+dsISXN/Lk

1791l/7NMB8GA1UdEQQYMBaBFEFsaWNlRFNTQGV4YW1wbGUuY29tMAkGByqGSM44BAMDMA
1792AwLQIUVQykGR9CK4lxIjONg2q1PWdrv0UCFQCfYVNSVAtcst3a53Yd4hBSW0NevTFj
1793MGECAQEwGDASMRAwDgYDVQQDEwdDYXJsRFNTAgIAyDAHBgUrDgMCGjAJBgcqhkjOOA
1794QDBC4wLAIUM/mGf6gkgp9Z0XtRdGimJeB/BxUCFGFFJqwYRt1WYcIOQoGiaowqGzVI
1795
1796------=_NextBoundry____Fri,_06_Sep_2002_00:25:21--
1797                </artwork>
1798                </figure>
1799                <t>
1800                  The content that is digested (the first part of the multipart/&wj;signed)
1801                  consists of the bytes:
1802                </t>
1803                <figure>
1804                  <artwork>
180554 68 69 73 20 69 73 20 73 6f 6d 65 20 73 61 6d 70 6c 65 20 63 6f 6e
180674 65 6e 74 2e 0d 0a
1807                  </artwork>
1808                </figure>
1809              </section>
1810            </section>
1811              </section>
1812            <section title="Creating a Compressed-Only Message">
1813              <t>
1814                This section describes the format for compressing a MIME entity.
1815                Please note that versions of S/&wj;MIME prior to version 3.1 did not
1816                specify any use of CompressedData, and will not recognize it.  The
1817                use of a capability to indicate the ability to receive CompressedData
1818                is described in <xref target="RFC3274"/> and is the preferred method for
1819                compatibility.
1820              </t>
1821              <t>
1822                <list style="format Step %d." hangIndent="9">
1823                <t>  The MIME entity to be compressed is prepared according to
1824                <xref target="MimePrep"/>.
1825</t>
1826                <t>  The MIME entity and other required data are processed into a
1827                CMS object of type CompressedData.
1828                </t>
1829                
1830                <t>  The CompressedData object is wrapped in a CMS ContentInfo
1831                object.
1832</t>
1833                <t>  The ContentInfo object is inserted into an
1834                application/&wj;pkcs7-mime MIME entity.
1835</t>
1836                </list>
1837              </t>
1838              <t>
1839                The smime-type parameter for compressed-only messages is "compressed-
1840                data".  The file extension for this type of message is ".p7z".
1841              </t>
1842              <t>
1843                A sample message would be:
1844              </t>
1845              <figure>
1846              <artwork>
1847Content-Type: application/pkcs7-mime; smime-type=compressed-data;
1848   name=smime.p7z
1849Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
1850Content-Disposition: attachment; filename=smime.p7z
1851
1852eNoLycgsVgCi4vzcVIXixNyCnFSF5Py8ktS8Ej0AlCkKVA==
1853              </artwork>
1854              </figure>
1855            </section>
1856            <section title="Multiple Operations" anchor="MultipleOperations">
1857              <t>
1858                The signed-only, enveloped-only, and compressed-only MIME formats can
1859                be nested.  This works because these formats are all MIME entities
1860                that encapsulate other MIME entities.
1861              </t>
1862              <t>
1863                An S/&wj;MIME implementation MUST be able to receive and process
1864                arbitrarily nested S/&wj;MIME within reasonable resource limits of the
1865                recipient computer.
1866              </t>
1867              <t>
1868                It is possible to apply any of the signing, encrypting, and
1869                compressing operations in any order.  It is up to the implementer and
1870                the user to choose.  When signing first, the signatories are then
1871                securely obscured by the enveloping.  When enveloping first the
1872                signatories are exposed, but it is possible to verify signatures
1873                without removing the enveloping.  This can be useful in an
1874                environment where automatic signature verification is desired, as no
1875                private key material is required to verify a signature.
1876              </t>
1877              <t>
1878                There are security ramifications to choosing whether to sign first or
1879                encrypt first.  A recipient of a message that is encrypted and then
1880                signed can validate that the encrypted block was unaltered, but
1881                cannot determine any relationship between the signer and the
1882                unencrypted contents of the message.  A recipient of a message that
1883                is signed then encrypted can assume that the signed message itself
1884                has not been altered, but that a careful attacker could have changed
1885                the unauthenticated portions of the encrypted message.
1886              </t>
1887              <t>
1888                When using compression, keep the following guidelines in mind:
1889                <list style="symbols">
1890                  <t>
1891                    Compression of binary encoded encrypted data is discouraged,
1892                    since it will not yield significant compression.  Base64
1893                    encrypted data could very well benefit, however.
1894                  </t>
1895                  <t>
1896                    If a lossy compression algorithm is used with signing, you will
1897                    need to compress first, then sign.
1898                  </t>
1899                </list>
1900              </t>
1901            </section>
1902            <section title="Creating a Certificate Management Message">
1903              <t>
1904                The certificate management message or MIME entity is used to
1905                transport certificates and/or Certificate Revocation Lists, such as
1906                in response to a registration request.
1907              </t>
1908              <t>
1909                <list style="format Step %d.">
1910                <t>  The certificates and/or Certificate Revocation Lists are
1911                made available to the CMS generating process that creates a
1912                CMS object of type SignedData.  The SignedData
1913                encapContentInfo eContent field MUST be absent and
1914                signerInfos field MUST be empty.
1915                </t>
1916<t>  The SignedData object is wrapped in a CMS ContentInfo
1917                object.
1918</t>
1919<t>  The ContentInfo object is enclosed in an
1920                application/&wj;pkcs7-mime MIME entity.
1921</t>
1922                </list>
1923              </t>
1924              <t>
1925                The smime-type parameter for a certificate management message is
1926                "certs-only".  The file extension for this type of message is ".p7c".
1927              </t>
1928            </section>
1929            <section title="Registration Requests">
1930              <t>
1931                A sending agent that signs messages MUST have a certificate for the
1932                signature so that a receiving agent can verify the signature.  There
1933                are many ways of getting certificates, such as through an exchange
1934                with a certification authority, through a hardware token or diskette,
1935                and so on.
1936              </t>
1937              <t>
1938                S/&wj;MIME v2 <xref target="SMIMEv2"/> specified a method for "registering" public keys
1939                with certificate authorities using an application/&wj;pkcs10 body part.
1940                Since that time, the IETF PKIX Working Group has developed other
1941                methods for requesting certificates.  However, S/&wj;MIME v4.0 does not
1942                require a particular certificate request mechanism.
1943              </t>
1944            </section>
1945            <section title="Identifying an S/MIME Message">
1946              <t>
1947                Because S/&wj;MIME takes into account interoperation in non-MIME
1948                environments, several different mechanisms are employed to carry the
1949                type information, and it becomes a bit difficult to identify S/&wj;MIME
1950                messages.  The following table lists criteria for determining whether
1951                or not a message is an S/&wj;MIME message.  A message is considered an
1952                S/&wj;MIME message if it matches any of the criteria listed below.
1953              </t>
1954              <t>
1955                The file suffix in the table below comes from the "name" parameter in
1956                the Content-Type header field, or the "filename" parameter on the
1957                Content-Disposition header field.  These parameters that give the
1958                file suffix are not listed below as part of the parameter section.
1959              </t>
1960              <texttable style="none">
1961                <ttcol>Media type</ttcol><ttcol>parameters</ttcol><ttcol>file suffix</ttcol>
1962                <c>application/pkcs7-mime</c><c>n/a</c><c>n/a</c>
1963                <c>multipart/signed</c><c>protocol= "application/pkcs7-signature"</c><c>n/a</c>
1964                <c>application/octet-stream</c><c>n/a</c><c>p7m, p7s, p7c, p7z</c>
1965              </texttable>
1966            </section>
1967          </section>
1968          <section title="Certificate Processing" anchor="CertProcessing">
1969            <t>
1970              A receiving agent MUST provide some certificate retrieval mechanism
1971              in order to gain access to certificates for recipients of digital
1972              envelopes.  This specification does not cover how S/&wj;MIME agents
1973              handle certificates, only what they do after a certificate has been
1974              validated or rejected.  S/&wj;MIME certificate issues are covered in
1975              <xref target="RFC5750"/>.
1976            </t>
1977            <t>
1978              At a minimum, for initial S/&wj;MIME deployment, a user agent could
1979              automatically generate a message to an intended recipient requesting
1980              that recipient's certificate in a signed return message.  Receiving
1981              and sending agents SHOULD also provide a mechanism to allow a user to
1982              "store and protect" certificates for correspondents in such a way so
1983              as to guarantee their later retrieval.
1984            </t>
1985            
1986            <section title="Key Pair Generation" anchor="KeyPairs">
1987              <t>
1988                All generated key pairs MUST be generated from a good source of non-deterministic random input <xref target="RFC4086"/> and the private key MUST be
1989                protected in a secure fashion.
1990              </t>
1991              
1992              <t>
1993                An S/&wj;MIME user agent MUST NOT generate asymmetric keys less than 2048 bits for use with an RSA signature algorithm.
1994              </t>
1995
1996              <t>
1997                For 2048-bit through 4096-bit RSA with SHA-256 see <xref target="RFC5754"/> and <xref target="FIPS186-4"/>.
1998                The first reference provides the signature algorithm's object identifier, and the second provides the signature algorithm's definition.
1999              </t>
2000              
2001              <t>
2002                For RSASSA-PSS with SHA-256, see <xref target="RFC4056"/>.
2003                For RSAES-OAEP, see <xref target="RFC3560"/>.
2004              </t>
2005            </section>
2006            
2007            <section title="Signature Generation">
2008              <t>
2009                The following are the requirements for an S/&wj;MIME agent generated RSA and
2010                RSASSA-PSS signatures:
2011              </t>
2012              <figure>
2013              <artwork>
2014        key size &lt;= 2047 : SHOULD NOT (Note 1)
20152048 &lt;= key size &lt;= 4096 : SHOULD     (see Security Considerations)
20164096 &lt;  key size         : MAY        (see Security Considerations)
2017
2018Note 1: see Historical Mail Considerations in Section 6.
2019Note 2: see Security Considerations in Appendix B.
2020              </artwork>
2021              </figure>
2022
2023              <t>
2024                Key sizes for ECDSA and EdDSA are fixed by the curve.
2025              </t>
2026              
2027            </section>
2028            
2029            <section title="Signature Verification">
2030              <t>
2031                The following are the requirements for S/&wj;MIME receiving agents during
2032                signature verification of RSA and RSASSA-PSS signatures:
2033              </t>
2034              <figure>
2035              <artwork>
2036        key size &lt;= 2047 : SHOULD NOT (Note 1)
20372048 &lt;= key size &lt;= 4096 : MUST       (Note 2)
20384096 &lt;  key size         : MAY        (Note 2)
2039
2040Note 1: see Historical Mail Considerations in Section 6.
2041Note 2: see Security Considerations in Appendix B.
2042              </artwork>
2043              </figure>
2044
2045              <t>
2046                Key sizes for ECDSA and EdDSA are fixed by the curve.
2047              </t>
2048            </section>
2049            
2050            <section title="Encryption">
2051              <t>
2052                The following are the requirements for an S/&wj;MIME agent when establishing keys for content encryption using the RSA, and RSA-OAEP algorithms:
2053              </t>
2054              <figure>
2055              <artwork>
2056        key size &lt;= 2047 : SHOULD NOT (Note 1)
20572048 &lt;= key size &lt;= 4096 : SHOULD     (Note 2)
20584096 &lt;  key size         : MAY        (Note 2)
2059
2060Note 1: see Historical Mail Considerations in Section 6.
2061Note 2: see Security Considerations in Appendix B.
2062              </artwork>
2063              </figure>
2064              
2065              <t>
2066                Key sizes for ECDH are fixed by the curve.
2067              </t>
2068            </section>
2069            
2070            <section title="Decryption">
2071              <!-- FIX ME -->
2072              <t>
2073                The following are the requirements for an S/&wj;MIME agent when
2074                establishing keys for content decryption using the RSA and RSAES-OAEP algorithms:
2075              </t>
2076              <figure>
2077              <artwork>
2078        key size &lt;= 2047 : MAY        (Note 1)
20792048 &lt;= key size &lt;= 4096 : MUST       (Note 2)
20804096 &lt;  key size         : MAY        (Note 2)
2081
2082Note 1: see Historical Mail Considerations in Section 6.
2083Note 2: see Security Considerations in Appendix B.
2084              </artwork>
2085              </figure>
2086
2087              <t>
2088                Key sizes for ECDH are fixed by the curve.
2089              </t>
2090              
2091            </section>
2092          </section>
2093          
2094          <section title="IANA Considerations" anchor="IANA">
2095            <t>
2096              The following information updates the media type registration for
2097              application/&wj;pkcs7-mime and application/&wj;pkcs7-signature to refer to
2098              this document as opposed to RFC 2311.
2099            </t>
2100            <t>
2101              Note that other documents can define additional MIME media types for
2102              S/&wj;MIME.
2103            </t>
2104
2105            <section title="Media Type for application/pkcs7-mime">
2106              <figure>
2107                <artwork>
2108                  
2109Type name: application
2110
2111Subtype Name: pkcs7-mime
2112
2113Required Parameters: NONE
2114
2115Optional Parameters: smime-type/signed-data
2116                     smime-type/enveloped-data
2117                     smime-type/compressed-data
2118                     smime-type/certs-only
2119                     name
2120
2121Encoding Considerations: See Section 3 of this document
2122
2123Security Considerations: See Section 6 of this document
2124
2125Interoperability Considerations: See Sections 1-6 of this document
2126
2127Published Specification: RFC 2311, RFC 2633, and this document
2128
2129Applications that use this media type: Security applications
2130
2131Additional information: NONE
2132
2133Person &amp; email to contact for further information: iesg@ietf.org
2134
2135Intended usage: COMMON
2136
2137Restrictions on usage: NONE
2138
2139Author: Sean Turner
2140
2141Change Controller: S/MIME working group delegated from the IESG
2142              </artwork>
2143              </figure>
2144            </section>
2145            <section title="Media Type for application/pkcs7-signature">
2146              <figure>
2147                <artwork>
2148                  
2149Type name: application
2150
2151Subtype Name: pkcs7-signature
2152
2153Required Parameters: NONE
2154
2155Optional Parameters: NONE
2156
2157Encoding Considerations: See Section 3 of this document
2158
2159Security Considerations: See Section 6 of this document
2160
2161Interoperability Considerations: See Sections 1-6 of this document
2162
2163Published Specification: RFC 2311, RFC 2633, and this document
2164
2165Applications that use this media type: Security applications
2166
2167Additional information: NONE
2168
2169Person &amp; email to contact for further information: iesg@ietf.org
2170
2171Intended usage: COMMON
2172
2173Restrictions on usage: NONE
2174
2175Author: Sean Turner
2176
2177Change Controller: S/MIME working group delegated from the IESG
2178              </artwork>
2179              </figure>
2180            </section>
2181
2182            <section title="Register authEnveloped-data smime-type">
2183              <t>
2184                IANA is required to register the following value in the "Parameter Values for the smime-type Parameter" registry.
2185                The values to be registered are:
2186                <cref source="JLS">
2187                  This can be done by modifying the registration above instead.
2188                </cref>
2189                <list style="none">
2190                  <t>smime-type value: authEnveloped-data</t>
2191                  <t>Reference: [[This Document, <xref target="smime-type"/>]]</t>
2192                </list>
2193              </t>
2194            </section>
2195          </section>
2196          <section title="Security Considerations" anchor="SecurityConsiderations">
2197            <t>
2198              Cryptographic algorithms will be broken or weakened over time.
2199              Implementers and users need to check that the cryptographic
2200              algorithms listed in this document continue to provide the expected
2201              level of security.  The IETF from time to time may issue documents
2202              dealing with the current state of the art.  For example:
2203              <list style="symbols">
2204                <t>
2205                  The Million Message Attack described in RFC 3218 <xref target="RFC3218"/>.
2206                </t>
2207                <t>
2208                  The Diffie-Hellman "small-subgroup" attacks described in RFC
2209                  2785 <xref target="RFC2785"/>.
2210                </t>
2211                <t>
2212                  The attacks against hash algorithms described in RFC 4270 <xref target="RFC4270"/>.
2213                </t>
2214              </list>
2215            </t>
2216            <t>
2217              This specification uses Public-Key Cryptography technologies.  It is
2218              assumed that the private key is protected to ensure that it is not
2219              accessed or altered by unauthorized parties.
2220            </t>
2221            <t>
2222              It is impossible for most people or software to estimate the value of
2223              a message's content.  Further, it is impossible for most people or
2224              software to estimate the actual cost of recovering an encrypted
2225              message content that is encrypted with a key of a particular size.
2226              Further, it is quite difficult to determine the cost of a failed
2227              decryption if a recipient cannot process a message's content.  Thus,
2228              choosing between different key sizes (or choosing whether to just use
2229              plaintext) is also impossible for most people or software.  However,
2230              decisions based on these criteria are made all the time, and
2231              therefore this specification gives a framework for using those
2232              estimates in choosing algorithms.
2233            </t>
2234            <t>
2235              The choice of 2048 bits as an RSA asymmetric key size in this
2236              specification is based on the desire to provide at least 100 bits of
2237              security.  The key sizes that must be supported to conform to this
2238              specification seem appropriate for the Internet based on <xref target="RFC3766"/>.
2239              Of course, there are environments, such as financial and medical
2240              systems, that may select different key sizes.  For this reason, an
2241              implementation MAY support key sizes beyond those recommended in this
2242              specification.
2243            </t>
2244            <t>
2245              Receiving agents that validate signatures and sending agents that
2246              encrypt messages need to be cautious of cryptographic processing
2247              usage when validating signatures and encrypting messages using keys
2248              larger than those mandated in this specification.  An attacker could
2249              send certificates with keys that would result in excessive
2250              cryptographic processing, for example, keys larger than those
2251              mandated in this specification, which could swamp the processing
2252              element.  Agents that use such keys without first validating the
2253              certificate to a trust anchor are advised to have some sort of
2254              cryptographic resource management system to prevent such attacks.
2255            </t>
2256            <t>
2257              Using weak cryptography in S/&wj;MIME offers little actual security over
2258              sending plaintext.  However, other features of S/&wj;MIME, such as the
2259              specification of AES and the ability to announce stronger
2260              cryptographic capabilities to parties with whom you communicate,
2261              allow senders to create messages that use strong encryption.  Using
2262              weak cryptography is never recommended unless the only alternative is
2263              no cryptography.
2264            </t>
2265            <t>
2266              RSA and DSA keys of less than 2048 bits are now considered by many
2267              experts to be cryptographically insecure (due to advances in
2268              computing power), and should no longer be used to protect messages.
2269              Such keys were previously considered secure, so processing previously
2270              received signed and encrypted mail will often result in the use of
2271              weak keys.  Implementations that wish to support previous versions of
2272              S/&wj;MIME or process old messages need to consider the security risks
2273              that result from smaller key sizes (e.g., spoofed messages) versus
2274              the costs of denial of service.  If an implementation supports
2275              verification of digital signatures generated with RSA and DSA keys of
2276              less than 1024 bits, it MUST warn the user.  Implementers should
2277              consider providing different warnings for newly received messages and
2278              previously stored messages.  Server implementations (e.g., secure
2279              mail list servers) where user warnings are not appropriate SHOULD
2280              reject messages with weak signatures.
2281            </t>
2282            <t>
2283              Implementers SHOULD be aware that multiple active key pairs can be
2284              associated with a single individual.  For example, one key pair can
2285              be used to support confidentiality, while a different key pair can be
2286              used for digital signatures.
2287            </t>
2288            <t>
2289              If a sending agent is sending the same message using different
2290              strengths of cryptography, an attacker watching the communications
2291              channel might be able to determine the contents of the strongly
2292              encrypted message by decrypting the weakly encrypted version.  In
2293              other words, a sender SHOULD NOT send a copy of a message using
2294              weaker cryptography than they would use for the original of the
2295              message.
2296            </t>
2297            <t>
2298              Modification of the ciphertext in EnvelopedData can go undetected if authentication is
2299              not also used, which is the case when sending EnvelopedData without
2300              wrapping it in SignedData or enclosing SignedData within it.
2301              This is one of the reasons for moving from EnvelopedData to AuthEnvelopedData as the authenticated encryption algorithms provide the authentication without needing the SignedData layer.
2302            </t>
2303            <t>
2304              If an implementation is concerned about compliance with National
2305              Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) key size
2306              recommendations, then see <xref target="SP800-57"/>.
2307            </t>
2308            <t>
2309              If messaging environments make use of the fact that a message is
2310              signed to change the behavior of message processing (examples would
2311              be running rules or UI display hints), without first verifying that
2312              the message is actually signed and knowing the state of the
2313              signature, this can lead to incorrect handling of the message.
2314              Visual indicators on messages may need to have the signature
2315              validation code checked periodically if the indicator is supposed to
2316              give information on the current status of a message.
2317            </t>
2318            <t>
2319              Many people assume that the use of an authenticated encryption algorithm is all that is needed to be in a situation where the sender of the message will be authenticated.
2320              In almost all cases this is not a correct statement.
2321              There are a number of preconditions that need to hold for an authenticated encryption algorithm to provide this service:
2322              <list style="symbols">
2323                <t>
2324                  The starting key must be bound to a single entity.
2325                  The use of a group key only would allow for the statement that a message was sent by one of the entities that held the key but will not identify a specific entity.
2326                </t>
2327                <t>
2328                  The message must have exactly one sender and one recipient.
2329                  Having more than one recipient would allow for the second recipient to create a message that the first recipient would believe is from the sender by stripping them as a recipient from the message.
2330                </t>
2331                <t>
2332                  A direct path needs to exist from the starting key to the key used as the content encryption key (CEK) which guarantees that no third party could have seen the resulting CEK.
2333                  This means that one needs to be using an algorithm that is called a "Direct Encryption" or a "Direct Key Agreement" algorithm in other contexts.
2334                  This means that the starting key is used directly as the CEK key, or that the starting key is used to create a secret which then is transformed into the CEK via a KDF step.
2335                </t>
2336              </list>
2337              S/MIME implementations almost universally use ephemeral-static rather than static-static key agreement and do not use a shared secret for encryption, this means that the first precondition is not met.
2338              There is a document <xref target="RFC6278"/> which defined how to use static-static key agreement with CMS so that is readably doable.
2339              Currently, all S/MIME key agreement methods derive a KEK and wrap a CEK.
2340              This violates the third precondition above.
2341              New key agreement algorithms that directly created the CEK without creating an intervening KEK would need to be defined.
2342            </t>
2343            <t>
2344              Even when all of the preconditions are met and origination of a message is established by the use of an authenticated encryption algorithm, users need to be aware that there is no way to prove this to a third party.
2345              This is because either of the parties can successfully create the message (or just alter the content) based on the fact that the CEK is going to be known to both parties.
2346              Thus the origination is always built on a presumption that "I did not send this message to myself."
2347            </t>
2348            <t>
2349              All of the authenticated encryption algorithms in this document use counter mode for the encryption portion of the algorithm.
2350              This means that the length of the plain text will always be known as the cipher text length and the plain text length are always the same.
2351              This information can enable passive observers to infer information based solely on the length of the message.
2352              Applications for which this is a concern need to provide some type of padding so that the length of the message does not provide this information.
2353            </t>
2354          </section>
2355  </middle>
2356  <back>
2357        <!--
2358            <displayreference target="RFC2785" to="DHSUB"/>

2421          </annotation>

2439          </annotation>

2454            <title>MIME Message Specifications</title>
2455            <author/>
2456            <date/>
2457          </front>
2458          <annotation>
2459            This is the set of documents that define how to use MIME.
2460            This set of documents is <xref target="RFC2045"/>, <xref target="RFC2046"/>, <xref target="RFC2047"/>, <xref target="RFC2049"/>, <xref target="RFC4288"/>, and <xref target="RFC4289"/>.
2461          </annotation>
2462        </reference>
2463
2464        <reference anchor="CHARSETS" target="http://www.iana.org/assignments/character-sets.">
2465          <front>
2466            <title>Character sets assigned by IANA.</title>
2467            <author/>

2470

2474          <front>
2475            <title>Digital Signature Standard (DSS)</title>
2476            <author><organization>National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)</organization></author>

2483        <reference anchor="ASN.1">
2484          <front>
2485            <title>Information Technology - Abstract Syntax Notation (ASN.1)</title>
2486            <author/>
2487            <date/>
2488          </front>
2489          <annotation>
2490            ASN.1 syntax consists of the following references <xref target="X.680"/>, <xref target="X.681"/>, <xref target="X.682"/>, and <xref target="X.683"/>.
2491          </annotation>
2492        </reference>
2493            
2494        <reference anchor="X.680">
2495          <front>
2496            <title>Information Technology - Abstract Syntax
2497            Notation One (ASN.1):  Specification of basic notation.
2498            ITU-T Recommendation X.680 (2002)
2499            </title>
2500            <author/>

2505        </reference>
2506
2507        <reference anchor="X.681">
2508          <front>
2509            <title>Information Technology - Abstract Syntax

2517        </reference>
2518
2519        <reference anchor="X.682">
2520          <front>
2521            <title>Information Technology - Abstract Syntax
2522            Notation One (ASN.1):  Constraint specification
2523            </title>
2524            <author/>
2525            <date month="November" year="2008"/>
2526          </front>
2527          <seriesInfo name="ITU-T" value="X.682"/>

2531        <reference anchor="X.683">
2532          <front>
2533            <title>Information Technology - Abstract Syntax
2534            Notation One (ASN.1):  Parameteriztion of ASN.1 specifications
2535            </title>
2536            <author/>
2537            <date month="November" year="2008"/>
2538          </front>
2539          <seriesInfo name="ITU-T" value="X.683"/>
2540          <seriesInfo name="ISO/IEC"  value="8824-4:2008"/>
2541        </reference>
2542
2543        <reference anchor="X.690">
2544          <front>
2545            <title>
2546              Information Technology - ASN.1 encoding
2547              rules: Specification of Basic Encoding Rules (BER),
2548              Canonical Encoding Rules (CER) and Distinguished
2549              Encoding Rules (DER).
2550            </title>
2551            <author/>
2552            <date month="July" year="2002"/>
2553          </front>
2554          <seriesInfo name="ITU-T" value="X.690"/>
2555          <seriesInfo name="ISO/IEC"  value="8825-1:2002"/>
2556        </reference>
2557
2558        <reference anchor="SMIMEv4.0">
2559          <front>
2560            <title>S/MIME version 4.0</title>
2561            <author/>
2562            <date/>
2563          </front>
2564          <annotation>
2565            This group of documents represents S/MIME version 4.0.
2566            This set of documents are <xref target="RFC2634"/>, <xref target="I-D.ietf-lamps-rfc5750-bis"/>, [[This Document]], <xref target="RFC5652"/>,  and <xref target="RFC5035"/>.
2567          </annotation>
2568        </reference>
2569
2570        &rfc5750bis;
2571
2572      </references>
2573      
2574      <references title="Informative References">
2575        &rfc2311; &rfc2312; &rfc2313; &rfc2314; &rfc2315;
2576        &rfc2630; &rfc2631; &rfc2632; &rfc2633;
2577        &rfc2785;
2578        &rfc3218;
2579        &rfc3850; &rfc3851; &rfc3852;
2580        &rfc4270;
2581        &rfc3766;
2582        &rfc5750; &rfc5751;
2583        &rfc4949;
2584        &rfc6278;
2585        &rfc6194; &rfc6151;
2586        &rfc2268;
2587        &rfc7905;
2588
2589        <!--
2590        <referencegroup target="SMIMEv2">
2591          &rfc2311;
2592          &rfc2312;
2593          &rfc2313;
2594          &rfc2314;
2595          &rfc2315;
2596        </referencegroup>
2597        -->
2598        <reference anchor="SMIMEv2">
2599          <front>
2600            <title>S/MIME version v2</title>
2601            <author/>
2602            <date/>
2603          </front>
2604          <annotation>
2605            This group of documents represents S/MIME version 2.
2606            This set of documents are <xref target="RFC2311"/>, <xref target="RFC2312"/>, <xref target="RFC2313"/>, <xref target="RFC2314"/>, and <xref target="RFC2315"/>.
2607          </annotation>
2608        </reference>
2609
2610      <!--
2611        <referencegroup target="SMIMEv3">
2612          &rfc2630;
2613          &rfc2631;
2614          &rfc2632;
2615          &rfc2633;
2616          &rfc2634;
2617          &rfc5035;
2618          </referencegroup>
2619          -->
2620
2621        <reference anchor="SMIMEv3">
2622          <front>
2623            <title>S/MIME version 3</title>
2624            <author/>
2625            <date/>
2626          </front>
2627          <annotation>
2628            This group of documents represents S/MIME version 3.
2629            This set of documents are <xref target="RFC2630"/>, <xref target="RFC2631"/>, <xref target="RFC2632"/>, <xref target="RFC2633"/>, <xref target="RFC2634"/>, and <xref target="RFC5035"/>.
2630          </annotation>
2631        </reference>
2632
2633        <!--

2640          </referencegroup>
2641        -->

2646            <author surname="Tuchman" initials="W."/>
2647            <date month="July" year="1979"/>
2648          </front>
2649          <seriesInfo name="IEEE Spectrum" value="v. 16, n. 7, pp 40-41"/>
2650        </reference>
2651

2653          <front>
2654            <title>S/MIME version 3.1</title>
2655            <author/>
2656            <date/>
2657          </front>
2658          <annotation>
2659            This group of documents represents S/MIME version 3.1.
2660            This set of documents are <xref target="RFC2634"/>, <xref target="RFC3850"/>, <xref target="RFC3851"/>, <xref target="RFC3852"/>,  and <xref target="RFC5035"/>.
2661          </annotation>
2662        </reference>
2663
2664
2665        <reference anchor="SMIMEv3.2">
2666          <front>
2667            <title>S/MIME version 3.2</title>
2668            <author/>
2669            <date/>
2670          </front>
2671          <annotation>
2672            This group of documents represents S/MIME version 3.2.
2673            This set of documents are <xref target="RFC2634"/>, <xref target="RFC5750"/>, <xref target="RFC5751"/>, <xref target="RFC5652"/>,  and <xref target="RFC5035"/>.
2674          </annotation>
2675        </reference>
2676
2677        <reference anchor="SP800-57">
2678          <front>
2679            <title>
2680              Special Publication 800-57: Recommendation for Key
2681              Management
2682            </title>
2683            <author><organization>
2684              National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)
2685            </organization>

2691        <reference anchor="FIPS186-2">
2692          <front>
2693            <title>Digital Signature Standard (DSS) [With Change Notice 1]</title>
2694            <author><organization>National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)</organization></author>
2695            <date month="January" year="2000"/>
2696          </front>

2698                      value="186-2"/>

2700
2701        
2702        <reference anchor="SP800-56A">
2703          <front>
2704            <title>Special Publication 800-56A Revision 2: Recommendation Pair-Wise Key Establishment Schemes Using Discrete Logarithm Cryptography</title>
2705            <author><organization>National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)</organization></author>
2706            <date month="May" year="2013"/>
2707          </front>

2710        &rfc7114;
2711        &rfc4134;

2713      </references>

2715
2716
2717
2718      <section title="ASN.1 Module" anchor="ASN1Module">
2719        <t>
2720Note: The ASN.1 module contained herein is unchanged from RFC 3851
2721<xref target="SMIMEv3.1"/> with the exception of a change to the prefersBinaryInside
2722ASN.1 comment.  This module uses the 1988 version of ASN.1.
2723        </t>
2724              <figure>
2725      <artwork>
2726SecureMimeMessageV3dot1
2727
2728  { iso(1) member-body(2) us(840) rsadsi(113549)
2729         pkcs(1) pkcs-9(9) smime(16) modules(0) msg-v3dot1(21) }
2730
2731DEFINITIONS IMPLICIT TAGS ::=
2732
2733BEGIN
2734
2735IMPORTS
2736
2737-- Cryptographic Message Syntax [CMS]
2738   SubjectKeyIdentifier, IssuerAndSerialNumber,
2739   RecipientKeyIdentifier
2740       FROM  CryptographicMessageSyntax
2741             { iso(1) member-body(2) us(840) rsadsi(113549)
2742               pkcs(1) pkcs-9(9) smime(16) modules(0) cms-2001(14) };
2743
2744--  id-aa is the arc with all new authenticated and unauthenticated
2745--  attributes produced by the S/MIME Working Group
2746
2747id-aa OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {iso(1) member-body(2) usa(840)
2748        rsadsi(113549) pkcs(1) pkcs-9(9) smime(16) attributes(2)}
2749
2750-- S/MIME Capabilities provides a method of broadcasting the
2751-- symmetric capabilities understood.  Algorithms SHOULD be ordered
2752-- by preference and grouped by type
2753
2754smimeCapabilities OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {iso(1) member-body(2)
2755        us(840) rsadsi(113549) pkcs(1) pkcs-9(9) 15}
2756
2757SMIMECapability ::= SEQUENCE {
2758   capabilityID OBJECT IDENTIFIER,
2759   parameters ANY DEFINED BY capabilityID OPTIONAL }
2760
2761SMIMECapabilities ::= SEQUENCE OF SMIMECapability
2762
2763-- Encryption Key Preference provides a method of broadcasting the
2764-- preferred encryption certificate.
2765
2766id-aa-encrypKeyPref OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {id-aa 11}
2767
2768SMIMEEncryptionKeyPreference ::= CHOICE {
2769   issuerAndSerialNumber   [0] IssuerAndSerialNumber,
2770   receipentKeyId          [1] RecipientKeyIdentifier,
2771   subjectAltKeyIdentifier [2] SubjectKeyIdentifier
2772}
2773
2774-- receipentKeyId is spelt incorrectly, but kept for historical
2775-- reasons.
2776
2777id-smime OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { iso(1) member-body(2) us(840)
2778        rsadsi(113549) pkcs(1) pkcs9(9) 16 }
2779
2780id-cap  OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-smime 11 }
2781
2782-- The preferBinaryInside OID indicates an ability to receive
2783-- messages with binary encoding inside the CMS wrapper.
2784-- The preferBinaryInside attribute's value field is ABSENT.
2785
2786id-cap-preferBinaryInside  OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-cap 1 }
2787
2788--  The following list OIDs to be used with S/MIME V3
2789
2790-- Signature Algorithms Not Found in [RFC3370], [RFC5754], [RFC4056],
2791-- and [RFC3560]
2792
2793--
2794-- md2WithRSAEncryption OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::=
2795--    {iso(1) member-body(2) us(840) rsadsi(113549) pkcs(1) pkcs-1(1)
2796--     2}
2797
2798--
2799-- Other Signed Attributes
2800--
2801-- signingTime OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::=
2802--    {iso(1) member-body(2) us(840) rsadsi(113549) pkcs(1) pkcs-9(9)
2803--     5}
2804--    See [CMS] for a description of how to encode the attribute
2805--    value.
2806
2807SMIMECapabilitiesParametersForRC2CBC ::= INTEGER
2808--        (RC2 Key Length (number of bits))
2809
2810END
2811      </artwork>
2812              </figure>
2813    </section>
2814
2815    <section title="Historic Mail Considerations" anchor="HistoricMail">
2816      <t>
2817        Over the course of updating the S/MIME specifications, the set of recommended algorithms has been modified each time the document has been updated.
2818        This means that if a user has historic emails and their user agent has been updated to only support the current set of recommended algorithms some of those old emails will no longer be accessible.
2819        It is strongly suggested that user agents implement some of the following algorithms for dealing with historic emails.
2820      </t>
2821
2822      <t>
2823        This appendix contains a number of references to documents that have been obsoleted or replaced, this is intentional as frequently the updated documents do not have the same information in them.
2824      </t>
2825
2826      <section title="DigestAlgorithmIdentifier">
2827        <t>
2828          The following algorithms have been called our for some level of support by previous S/MIME specifications:
2829          <list style="symbols">
2830            <t>
2831              SHA&nbhy;1 was dropped in <xref target="SMIMEv4.0"/>.
2832              SHA-1 is no longer considerd to be secure as it is no longer collision-resistant.
2833              The IETF statement on SHA-1 can be found in <xref target="RFC6194"/> but it is out-of-date relative to the most recent advances.
2834            </t>
2835            <t>
2836              MD5 was dropped in <xref target="SMIMEv4.0"/>.
2837              MD5 is no longer considered to be secure as it is no longer collision-resistant.
2838              Details can be found in <xref target="RFC6151"/>.
2839            </t>
2840          </list>
2841        </t>
2842              
2843      </section>
2844      
2845      <section title="Signature Algorithms">
2846        <t>
2847          There are a number of problems with validating signatures on sufficently historic messages.
2848          For this reason it is strongly suggested that UAs treat these signatures differently from those on current messages.
2849          These problems include:
2850          <list style="symbols">
2851            <t>
2852              CAs are not required to keep certificates on a CRL beyond one update after a certificate has expired.
2853              This means that unless CRLs are cached as part of the message it is not always possible to check if a certificate has been revoked.
2854              The same problems exist with OCSP responses as they may be based on a CRL rather than on the certificate database.
2855            </t>
2856            <t>
2857              RSA and DSA keys of less than 2048 bits are now considered by many experts to be cryptographically insecure (due to advances in computing power).
2858              Such keys were previously considered secure, so processing of historic  signed messages  will often result in the use of weak keys.
2859              Implementations that wish to support previous versions of S/&wj;MIME or process old messages need to consider the security risks that result from smaller key sizes (e.g., spoofed messages) versus the costs of denial of service.
2860              <vspace blankLines="1"/>
2861              <xref target="SMIMEv3.1"/> set the lower limit on suggested key sizes for creating and validation at 1024 bits.
2862              Prior to that the lower bound on key sizes was 512 bits.
2863            </t>
2864            <t>
2865              Hash functions used to validate signatures on historic messages may longer be considered to be secure.
2866              (See below.)
2867              While there are not currently any known practical pre-image or second pre-image attacks against MD5 or SHA&nbhy;1, the fact they are no longer considered to be collision resistent the security levels of the signatures are generally considered suspect.
2868              If a message is known to be historic, that it it has been in the possession of the client for some time, then it might still be considered to be secure.
2869            </t>
2870            <t>
2871              The previous two issues apply to the certificates used to validate the binding of the public key to the identity that signed the message as well.
2872            </t>
2873          </list>
2874        </t>
2875        <t>
2876          The following algorithms have been called out for some level of support by previous S/MIME specifications:
2877          <list style="symbols">
2878            <t>
2879              RSA with MD5 was dropped in <xref target="SMIMEv4.0"/>.
2880              MD5 is no longer considered to be secure as it is no longer collision-resistant.
2881              Details can be found in <xref target="RFC6151"/>.
2882            </t>
2883            <t>
2884              RSA and DSA with SHA&nbhy;1 were dropped in <xref target="SMIMEv4.0"/>.
2885              SHA-1 is no longer considered to be secure as it is no longer collision-resistant.
2886              The IETF statment on SHA-1 can be found in <xref target="RFC6194"/> but it is out-of-date relative to the most recent advances.
2887            </t>
2888            <t>
2889              DSA with SHA-256 was dropped in <xref target="SMIMEv4.0"/>.
2890              DSA has been replaced by elliptic curve versions.
2891            </t>
2892          </list>
2893        </t>
2894
2895        <t>
2896          As requirements for mandatory to implement has changed over time, some issues have been created that can cause interoperability problems:
2897          <list style="symbols">
2898            <t>
2899              S/&wj;MIME v2 clients are only required to verify digital signatures using the rsaEncryption algorithm with SHA&nbhy;1 or MD5, and might not implement id-dsa-with-sha1 or id-dsa at all.
2900            </t>
2901            <t>
2902              S/&wj;MIME v3 clients might only implement signing or signature verification using id-dsa-with-sha1, and might also use id-dsa as an AlgorithmIdentifier in this field.
2903            </t>
2904            <t>
2905              Note that S/&wj;MIME v3.1 clients support verifying id-dsa-with-sha1 and rsaEncryption and might not implement sha256withRSAEncryption.
2906            </t>
2907          </list>
2908        </t>
2909
2910        <t>
2911          NOTE: Receiving clients SHOULD recognize id-dsa as equivalent to id-dsa-with-sha1.
2912        </t>
2913
2914        <t>
2915          For 512-bit RSA with SHA&nbhy;1 see <xref target="RFC3370"/> and <xref target="FIPS186-2"/> without Change Notice 1, for 512-bit RSA with SHA-256 see <xref target="RFC5754"/> and <xref target="FIPS186-2"/> without Change Notice 1, and for 1024-bit through 2048-bit RSA with SHA-256 see <xref target="RFC5754"/> and <xref target="FIPS186-2"/> with Change Notice 1.
2916          The first reference provides the signature algorithm's object identifier, and the second provides the signature algorithm's definition.
2917        </t>
2918
2919        <t>
2920          For 512-bit DSA with SHA&nbhy;1 see <xref target="RFC3370"/> and <xref target="FIPS186-2"/> without Change Notice 1, for 512-bit DSA with SHA-256 see <xref target="RFC5754"/> and <xref target="FIPS186-2"/> without Change Notice 1, for 1024-bit DSA with SHA&nbhy;1 see <xref target="RFC3370"/> and <xref target="FIPS186-2"/> with Change Notice 1, for 1024-bit and above DSA with SHA-256 see <xref target="RFC5754"/> and <xref target="FIPS186-4"/>.
2921          The first reference provides the signature algorithm's object identifier and the second provides the signature algorithm's definition.
2922        </t>
2923        
2924      </section>
2925
2926      <section title="ContentEncryptionAlgorithmIdentifier">
2927        <t>
2928          The following algorithms have been called out for some level of support by previous S/MIME specifications:
2929          <list style="symbols">
2930            <t>
2931              RC2/40 <xref target="RFC2268"/> was dropped in <xref target="SMIMEv3.2"/>.
2932              The algorithm is known to be insecure and, if supported, should only be used to decrypt existing email.
2933            </t>
2934            <t>
2935              DES EDE3 CBC <xref target="TripleDES"/>, also known as "tripleDES" is dropped in <xref target="SMIMEv4.0"/>.
2936              This algorithms is removed from the supported list due to the fact that it has a 64-bit block size and the fact that it offers less that 128-bits of security.
2937              This algorithm should be supported only to decrypt existing email, it should not be used to encrypt new emails.
2938            </t>
2939          </list>
2940        </t>
2941      </section>
2942
2943      <section title="KeyEncryptionAlgorithmIdentifier">
2944        <t>
2945          The following algorithms have been called out for some level of support by previous S/MIME specifications:
2946          <list style="symbols">
2947            <t>
2948              DH ephemeral-static mode, as specified in
2949              <xref target="RFC3370"/> and <xref target="SP800-57"/>, was dropped in <xref target="SMIMEv4.0"/>.
2950              
2951            </t>
2952            <t>
2953              RSA key sizes have been increased over time.
2954              Decrypting old mail with smaller key sizes is reasonable, however new mail should use the updated key sizes.
2955            </t>
2956          </list>
2957        </t>
2958
2959        <t>
2960          For 1024-bit DH, see <xref target="RFC3370"/>.
2961          For 1024-bit and larger DH, see <xref target="SP800-56A"/>; regardless, use the KDF, which is from X9.42, specified in <xref target="RFC3370"/>.
2962        </t>
2963              
2964      </section>
2965    </section>
2966
2967    <section title="Moving S/MIME v2 Message Specification to Historic Status" anchor="V2Historic">
2968      <t>
2969        The S/&wj;MIME v3 <xref target="SMIMEv3"/>, v3.1 <xref target="SMIMEv3.1"/>, and v3.2 <xref target="SMIMEv3.2"/>
2970        are backwards compatible with the S/&wj;MIME v2 Message Specification
2971        <xref target="SMIMEv2"/>, with the exception of the algorithms (dropped RC2/40
2972        requirement and added DSA and RSASSA-PSS requirements).  Therefore,
2973        it is recommended that RFC 2311 <xref target="SMIMEv2"/> be moved to Historic
2974        status.
2975      </t>
2976    </section>
2977
2978    
2979    <section title="Acknowledgments">
2980      <t>
2981        Many thanks go out to the other authors of the S/&wj;MIME version 2
2982        Message Specification RFC: Steve Dusse, Paul Hoffman, Laurence
2983        Lundblade, and Lisa Repka.  Without v2, there wouldn't be a v3, v3.1,
2984        v3.2 or v4.0.
2985      </t>
2986      <t>
2987        Some of the examples in this document were stolen from <xref target="RFC4134"/>.
2988        Thanks go the the people who wrote and verified the examples in that document.
2989      </t>
2990      <t>
2991        A number of the members of the S/&wj;MIME Working Group have also worked
2992        very hard and contributed to this document.  Any list of people is
2993        doomed to omission, and for that I apologize.  In alphabetical order,
2994        the following people stand out in my mind because they made direct
2995        contributions to various versions of this document:
2996      </t>
2997      <t>
2998        Tony Capel, Piers Chivers, Dave Crocker, Bill Flanigan, Peter
2999        Gutmann, Alfred Hoenes, Paul Hoffman, Russ Housley, William Ottaway,
3000        and John Pawling.
3001      </t>
3002  <t>
3003    The version 4 update to the S/&wj;MIME documents was done under the auspices of the LAMPS Working Group.
3004  </t>
3005
3006    </section>
3007  </back>
3008</rfc>
  • <?rfc toc='yes'?>
  • <?rfc symrefs='yes'?>
  • <?rfc sortrefs='yes' ?>
  • <?rfc compact='yes'?>
  • <?rfc subcompact='no' ?>
  • <?rfc text-list-symbols='-*o" ?>
  • <rfc ipr="pre5378Trust200902" docName="draft-ietf-lamps-rfc5751-bis-latest" category="std" obsoletes="5751" updates="" submissionType="IETF" {http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace}lang="en">
    • <front>
      • <title abbrev="S/MIME 4.0 Message Specification">
        • Secure/Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (S/MIME) Version 4.0 Message Specification
        • </title>
      • <seriesInfo name="Internet-Draft" value="draft-ietf-lamps-rfc5751-bis-latest"/>
      • <seriesInfo name="std" value=""/>
      • <author fullname="Jim Schaad" initials="J." surname="Schaad">
        • <organization>
          • August Cellars
          • </organization>
        • <address>
          • <email>
            • ietf@augustcellars.com
            • </email>
          • </address>
        • </author>
      • <author fullname="Blake Ramsdell" initials="B." surname="Ramsdell">
        • <organization>
          • Brute Squad Labs, Inc.
          • </organization>
        • <address>
          • <email>
            • blaker@gmail.com
            • </email>
          • </address>
        • </author>
      • <author fullname="Sean Turner" initials="S." surname="Turner">
        • <organization>
          • sn3rd
          • </organization>
        • <address>
          • <email>
            • sean@sn3rd.com
            • </email>
          • </address>
        • </author>
      • <date/>
      • <area>
        • Security Area
        • </area>
      • <workgroup>
        • LAMPS
        • </workgroup>
      • <keyword>
        • S/MIME
        • </keyword>
      • <abstract>
        • <t>
          • This document defines Secure/Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (S/MIME) version 4.0. S/MIME provides a consistent way to send and receive secure MIME data. Digital signatures provide authentication, message integrity, and non-repudiation with proof of origin. Encryption provides data confidentiality. Compression can be used to reduce data size. This document obsoletes RFC 5751.
          • </t>
        • </abstract>
      • <note title="Contributing to this document">
        • <name>
          • Contributing to this document
          • </name>
        • <t>
          • The source for this draft is being maintained in GitHub. Suggested changes should be submitted as pull requests at
          • <eref target="https://github.com/lamps-wg/smime"/>
          • . Instructions are on that page as well. Editorial changes can be managed in GitHub, but any substantial issues need to be discussed on the LAMPS mailing list.
          • </t>
        • </note>
      • </front>
    • <middle>
      • <section title="Introduction" numbered="true" toc="default">
        • <name>
          • Introduction
          • </name>
        • <t>
          • S/MIME (Secure/Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions) provides a consistent way to send and receive secure MIME data. Based on the popular Internet MIME standard, S/MIME provides the following cryptographic security services for electronic messaging applications: authentication, message integrity and non-repudiation of origin (using digital signatures), and data confidentiality (using encryption). As a supplementary service, S/MIME provides for message compression.
          • </t>
        • <t>
          • S/MIME can be used by traditional mail user agents (MUAs) to add cryptographic security services to mail that is sent, and to interpret cryptographic security services in mail that is received. However, S/MIME is not restricted to mail; it can be used with any transport mechanism that transports MIME data, such as HTTP or SIP. As such, S/MIME takes advantage of the object-based features of MIME and allows secure messages to be exchanged in mixed-transport systems.
          • </t>
        • <t>
          • Further, S/MIME can be used in automated message transfer agents that use cryptographic security services that do not require any human intervention, such as the signing of software-generated documents and the encryption of FAX messages sent over the Internet.
          • </t>
        • <section title="Specification Overview" anchor="SpecOverview" numbered="true" toc="default">
          • <name>
            • Specification Overview
            • </name>
          • <t>
            • This document describes a protocol for adding cryptographic signature and encryption services to MIME data. The MIME standard
            • <xref target="MIME-SPEC" pageno="false" format="default"/>
            • provides a general structure for the content of Internet messages and allows extensions for new content-type-based applications.
            • </t>
          • <t>
            • This specification defines how to create a MIME body part that has been cryptographically enhanced according to the Cryptographic Message Syntax (CMS)
            • <xref target="CMS" pageno="false" format="default"/>
            • , which is derived from PKCS #7
            • <xref target="RFC2315" pageno="false" format="default"/>
            • . This specification also defines the application/pkcs7-mime media type that can be used to transport those body parts.
            • </t>
          • <t>
            • This document also discusses how to use the multipart/signed media type defined in
            • <xref target="RFC1847" pageno="false" format="default"/>
            • to transport S/MIME signed messages. multipart/signed is used in conjunction with the application/pkcs7-signature media type, which is used to transport a detached S/MIME signature.
            • </t>
          • <t>
            • In order to create S/MIME messages, an S/MIME agent MUST follow the specifications in this document, as well as the specifications listed in the Cryptographic Message Syntax document
            • <xref target="CMS" pageno="false" format="default"/>
            • ,
            • <xref target="RFC3370" pageno="false" format="default"/>
            • ,
            • <xref target="RFC4056" pageno="false" format="default"/>
            • ,
            • <xref target="RFC3560" pageno="false" format="default"/>
            • , and
            • <xref target="RFC5754" pageno="false" format="default"/>
            • .
            • </t>
          • <t>
            • Throughout this specification, there are requirements and recommendations made for how receiving agents handle incoming messages. There are separate requirements and recommendations for how sending agents create outgoing messages. In general, the best strategy is to "be liberal in what you receive and conservative in what you send". Most of the requirements are placed on the handling of incoming messages, while the recommendations are mostly on the creation of outgoing messages.
            • </t>
          • <t>
            • The separation for requirements on receiving agents and sending agents also derives from the likelihood that there will be S/MIME systems that involve software other than traditional Internet mail clients. S/MIME can be used with any system that transports MIME data. An automated process that sends an encrypted message might not be able to receive an encrypted message at all, for example. Thus, the requirements and recommendations for the two types of agents are listed separately when appropriate.
            • </t>
          • </section>
        • <section title="Definitions" anchor="Definitions" numbered="true" toc="default">
          • <t>
            • For the purposes of this specification, the following definitions apply.
            • </t>
          • <t>
            • <list style="hanging" hangIndent="19">
              • <t hangText="ASN.1:">
                • Abstract Syntax Notation One, as defined in ITU-T Recommendations X.680, X.681, X.682 and X.683
                • <xref target="ASN.1" pageno="false" format="default"/>
                • .
                • </t>
              • <t hangText="BER:">
                • Basic Encoding Rules for ASN.1, as defined in ITU-T Recommendation X.690
                • <xref target="X.690" pageno="false" format="default"/>
                • .
                • </t>
              • <t hangText="Certificate:">
                • A type that binds an entity's name to a public key with a digital signature.
                • </t>
              • <t hangText="DER:">
                • Distinguished Encoding Rules for ASN.1, as defined in ITU-T Recommendation X.690
                • <xref target="X.690" pageno="false" format="default"/>
                • .
                • </t>
              • <t hangText="7-bit data:">
                • Text data with lines less than 998 characters long, where none of the characters have the 8th bit set, and there are no NULL characters. <CR> and <LF> occur only as part of a <CR><LF> end-of- line delimiter.
                • </t>
              • <t hangText="8-bit data:">
                • Text data with lines less than 998 characters, and where none of the characters are NULL characters. <CR> and <LF> occur only as part of a <CR><LF> end-of-line delimiter.
                • </t>
              • <t hangText="Binary data:">
                • Arbitrary data.
                • </t>
              • <t hangText="Transfer encoding:">
                • A reversible transformation made on data so 8-bit or binary data can be sent via a channel that only transmits 7-bit data.
                • </t>
              • <t hangText="Receiving agent:">
                • Software that interprets and processes S/MIME CMS objects, MIME body parts that contain CMS content types, or both.
                • </t>
              • <t hangText="Sending agent:">
                • Software that creates S/MIME CMS content types, MIME body parts that contain CMS content types, or both.
                • </t>
              • <t hangText="S/MIME agent:">
                • User software that is a receiving agent, a sending agent, or both.
                • </t>
              • <t hangText="Data Integrity Service:">
                • A security service that protects against unauthorized changes to data by ensuring that changes to the data are detectable.
